Award.AwardTitle: Building Capacity to Increase the Pool of Highly Qualified STEM Teachers in High-Need Texas School Districts with Predominantly Hispanic Student Populations
Award.AbstractNarration: This project aims to address the need for science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) K-12 teachers at both the national and regional level. Toward this aim, St. Mary’s University, a four-year Hispanic Serving Institution in San Antonio, Texas, will work with local education agency partners to evaluate and build capacity within its STEM Teacher Certification programs. The project will focus broadly on improving the pipeline for STEM majors seeking teacher licensure. In addition, it will encourage STEM pre-service teachers to teach in high-need schools and develop strategies and resources to support STEM pre-service teachers through their undergraduate studies and early stages of their professional K-12 teaching careers. This effort will include a careful investigation of available resources that might influence the development of an effective teacher preparation program and partnerships with local school districts. The project will also work to understand factors that impact Hispanic and other students as they make educational and career choices. <br/><br/>This project at St. Mary’s University includes partnerships with the Northside Independent School District (Northside ISD) and the San Antonio ISD. Project goals include: 1) analyzing baseline data to explore the need for highly qualified STEM teachers in the partner local education agencies; 2) understanding the motivations and obstacles faced by Hispanic and other students as they make educational and career choices, particularly whether to major in STEM fields and to pursue a career as a K-12 STEM educator; 3) evaluating the existing university infrastructure for a robust program for student recruitment and STEM teacher preparation; and 4) developing a comprehensive plan to enhance the University’s ability to (a) successfully recruit, retain, and graduate talented students as STEM teachers; and (b) to support them during their first year as teachers in high-needs school districts. The project will generate new knowledge about effective recruiting and support mechanisms for diverse pre-service teachers, in partnership with school districts that have predominantly Hispanic student populations. Project outcomes are expected to contribute to ongoing efforts to broaden participation in K-12 STEM teaching. This Capacity Building project is supported through the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program (Noyce). The Noyce program supports talented STEM undergraduate majors and professionals to become effective K-12 STEM teachers and experienced, exemplary K-12 teachers to become STEM master teachers in high-need school districts. It also supports research on the persistence, retention, and effectiveness of K-12 STEM teachers in high-need school districts.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
St. Mary’s University (StMU), a four-year private university located in San Antonio, Texas, is a recognized Hispanic-Serving Institution (HSI). The goal of our 2021-2022 "Capacity-Building Partnership to Increase the Pool of Highly Qualified STEM Teachers in Two High-Needs Texas School Districts with Predominantly Hispanic Student Populations" project is to develop innovative evidence-based strategies for recruiting, retaining, and preparing a diverse pool of students to teach STEM subjects in high-needs middle and high schools. In pursuing this goal, we evaluated our existing STEM with Teacher Certification programs to identify opportunities to redesign, expand, or create new programming and services, to improve coordination in the delivery of student support, and strengthen communication and collaboration among faculty and students in the StMU School of Science, Engineering, and Technology (SET) and the StMU Education Department/Educator Preparation Program (EPP). As a key component of this effort, we worked to strengthen and expand our local education agency (LEA) partnerships with the San Antonio and Northside Independent School Districts (SAISD and NISD), two high-needs districts that educate predominantly Hispanic and other minority students.

Specifically, we worked with our LEA partners to (i) understand district needs, policies, and practices more fully; (ii) identify strengths and weaknesses of our existing EPP so that we can jointly develop strategies to better support early stage STEM educators to ensure they are both highly effective and more likely to remain in the teaching profession, and; (iii) develop a full NSF Noyce Track 1 (Scholarships & Stipends) proposal to support students pursuing a STEM with Teacher Certification Degree at St. Mary's.

In collaboration with our LEA partners, we developed and administered online surveys to explore the perspectives of in-service STEM teachers and administrators for SAISD and NISD with respect to the challenges they face in STEM instruction. Pandemic conditions throughout the 2021-2022 school-year prevented access to school campuses, and we were limited to online or virtual (Zoom) interactions. We worked with the StMU Office of Enrollment Management to develop a text-based survey for prospective students to gauge their awareness of, and openness to, STEM teaching as a potential career path. Finally, we conducted virtual interviews with recent graduates from our STEM with Teacher Certification programs who are currently early in their middle/high school teaching careers at five different (3 urban/suburban, 2 rural) school districts around Texas.

Survey results (n=94) of in-service STEM teachers/administrators clearly identified classroom management skills as most important during the first few years of teaching. Other topics identified in survey results included pre-service training on the “reality of teaching”, “communicating with/managing parents”, and “dealing with hostile students”. In-service teachers and administrators noted that COVID-19 experiences have highlighted a need for training in social emotional learning (SEL) and trauma-informed teaching. Survey results also indicated there is a need to prepare teachers to differentiate instruction to meet the behavioral needs of their students and to meet the needs of English-Language Learners.

Interviews with recent StMU graduates who are now in-service STEM teachers yielded similar experiences to the online surveys of SAISD and NISD teachers and administrators. For example, our graduates indicated that while they felt well-prepared with respect to STEM content, classroom management presented the biggest challenge they faced at the beginning of their teaching career. They also identified establishing cultural relevance as an important key to success in STEM instruction (“Math needs to be meaningful to the student”). In addition to career insights, our graduates also identified supports that would have been a benefit during their undergraduate studies at St. Mary’s. For example, some interviewees noted that because most of their StMU EPP peers were non-STEM majors, they experienced a sense of isolation in their pedagogy classes; they “…wanted more peers in STEM teaching”. Those interviewed also highlighted continued contact from StMU after graduation, including informal contact such as “How are you doing” as key during the first years in the classroom. These results helped us identify opportunities to revise and strengthen our EPP curriculum, improve tracking students  through graduation into their careers, and student/teacher induction supports.

Surveys of prospective STEM students indicate an openness to the idea of STEM teaching as a career path. Approximately 53 percent of respondents (n=83) indicated that they either had “not thought about it before” (22.9%), or would “possibly be interested in learning more” (30.1%). This is consistent with survey results from in-service teachers/administrators at SAISD and NISD who commented that STEM undergraduates are “generally not aware of teaching as a potential career path”. Results suggest a pool of receptive students who can be approached by targeted recruiting strategies to raise awareness of STEM teaching as a career option.

We used insights from evaluating our EPP and survey results to design coordinated systems of student and graduate supports as part of a comprehensive Track 1 proposal submitted to NSF in August 2022.
